message:
I've been searching for something like this for my last project. I haven't tested it yet but David Walsh can be trusted
Uncss will remove unused CSS elements.
http://davidwalsh.name/uncss
Let us know what you think, UI people?
caption: Attachment UnavailableThis attachment may have been removed or the person who shared it may not have permission to share it with you.

data.message:
This is great especially when you're using a front end framework
Thanks

I remember that I used bootstrap on a website & found that 92% of it was unused!

Uncss is a very useful tool, but it must be used with care.
My only advice is that this tool must be used only at the end of a project so you be sure that you won't need those unused CSS rules
I think it could be added to the 'build' steps of the project, along with JS minification.

most of these tools is not accurate because they check your css against 1 page or even when you minify all your css you still reserve some code you use in the Admin. Use it on your own responsibility.

I have used this tool as a part of my Grunt *build* ... It check all the files in your website. It uses phantom JS and send a headless browser so all dynamically created elements (like sliders, rotators, whatever you call them) will be parsed too ... It is awesome it reduce your CSS by 90% if you are using a framework like Bootstrap or Foundation or any similar one ... In my experience, this tool is awesome and a MUST have. If I had the chance to meet Addy Osmani IRL I will probably faint and ask him to marry me :D
Dude, don't say that last part. That actually mean something now.
LOL ... I am just grateful for the guy ... I learned a lot from his backbone books and his other contributions
